title: How many total deaths attributed to COVID-19 will have been reported by the World Health Organization (WHO) for Brazil as of 1 October 2020?
preds:
Currently at 141,741 deaths. Average daily deaths over the last few weeks has been about 700-800/day.
With 1-2 days left to report, its very unlikely its going to make it to over 150,000.
Recent daily tolls have been around 1,000 per day. As of 9/29 there are 141k deaths.

Currently Brazil has just under 140K deaths.  Currently case rates are trending down by about 7% and death rates trending down by about 10%.  Even if they trend slightly upward 99.9% chance they remain under 150K.

https://tradingeconomics.com/brazil/coronavirus-deaths
http://www.xinhuanet.com/english/2020-09/10/c_139357070.htm
https://covid19.who.int/region/amro/country/br  The peak appears to average at 1000 deaths per day  that would give a figure of less than 150,000 by October 1st.
Currently around 136K deaths.  Daily rate around 850 but increasing trend.  Even assuming 900 deaths daily for 10 days still won’t pass 150K.  But still a small chance.

Hopkins tags Brazil at 134,495 deaths (actually yesterday's numbers posted today, link https://coronavirus.jhu.edu/region/brazil The Brazil media consortium (not connected to gov) is using the number 136,000, and the official government figure is just over 135,000. And WHO is just over 134,000 deaths link https://covid19.who.int/region/amro/country/br It is not likely that any organization will show an average of 1,250 deaths per day to take the number over 150,000.
Okay, no data adjustment in the next 2 weeks after so many months without. 100%.
Today there are 132k death, so it will stay in that bracket with no more than 150k.

Update 13th september 2020: Current figure: 131K total deaths attributed to COVID-19. The linear approximation forumula of the trend of the recent 21 days concerning new deaths attributed to COVID-19 per Day on a 7-day average is  d(x) = -12.91*x + 1001.4  where x is 0 for 08/22/2020 and d(x) is the number of new deaths on day x. [1]  This is a significant change in the gradient since the last linear approximation: d(x)=-19,99*x + 1027 but still the daily increase is decreasing - just not that fast anymore.  According to this approximattion there will be another 9K deaths until 1 October 2020 summing up to a total of approximately 140K deaths.  => Increasing the probability to 95% for the range [120K,150K).  [1] http://91-divoc.com/pages/covid-visualization/?chart=countries&highlight=Brazil&show=25&y=highlight&scale=linear&data=deaths-daily-7&data-source=jhu&xaxis=right-4wk#countries

18 days to go, approx 20k to reach 150k needed, still running at about 1k per day, but now rates have dropped off slightly, can’t see how 150k will be reached un,ses there is a massive restatement of numbers somewhere.

23 days between now and October 1, and Brazil has averaged around 700 deaths per day over the past week, which suggest around 16k more deaths by Oct 1. Since Brazil has 127k deaths, it looks like Brazil will end up well short of 150k deaths.
Adjusting down with recent decrease in 7d avg

126203 as of 7 September, 24 days to go. Almost 1000 per day required for bin 4, 7-day moving average below 800, daily new cases going down. This is done. I´m giving it 99% "only" because of the vague possibility of a data adjustment.

I looked the at all Brazil graphs (cumulative cases, new cases, cumulative deaths, new deaths) on the W.H.O. dashboard page again.
I noticed that
/the cumulative  cases graph changed slope and became steeper around 01 August 2020, the reason for this being the two peaks in new cases on 25 July 2020 (60k) and 31 July 2020 (69k). Interestingly, the number of new deaths peaked only once, on 31 July 2020 (1,595), followed by a smaller high on 07 August 2020 (1,437).
/This indicates there is a loose correlation with a time lag for Brazil of maybe 7 to 8 days. After changing to the 3rd bin yesterday, I now decided to roll back partially, because of one thing that has caught my attention in the graph: after a declining trend in new cases for most of August 2020 (consecutive highs are always lower than the previous one), for the first time in two weeks the weekly high rose again and on 06 September 2020 surpassed 51k new cases again.
I predict a change in general trend of new cases there, and predict it will be associated with a change in trend of new deaths around 14 September 2020, after which, I assume, the weekly lows (e.g. 366 deaths on 01 September 2020) will lie at 850 or higher for the remaining two weeks. The death toll of 5 of the 7 weekdays should then be no lower than 1,200. The last two days of the question, Wednesday 30 September 2020 and Thursday 01 October 2020, are weekdays that use to turn out strong after the weekly lows that use to be on Mondays and Tuesdays.
I can imagine that the last two days will bring values of 1,400 each. All put together, the sum of new deaths in my projection between 14 September and 01 October 2020 could be 18,200 fatalities. Combined with the 126,203 as of 07 Sept 2020, the total excluding the period 08 September through 13 September 2020 would be 144,400 fatalities.
To me, it will all come down to how fast any rise in new cases will feed into the number of new fatalities, and whether the six days between today Tuesday (low number expected) 08 September and Sunday (possibly a lower number, too) 13 September 2020 will turn out with a sum of 6,000 or more fatalities (1,000 per day on average). Meanwhile, I switch to bin 4 contrary to the crowd. The risk is high, but - as mentioned very early and several times before, it'll be very close, and may even depend on the single last turnout.  I'll want to wait what this week brings.

Moving to the crowd forecast. The trend shows the result will be close to 150k, but most likely just below - a change in direction will be needed for it to increase sufficiently to be above this number.

Months ago, I thought Brazil would be close to the 180000 mark. However, cases and deaths neither really climbed or plateaued at any point and infection rates/deaths have been steady. At that rate, I knew it would be close, but now I am finally adjusting my forecast to mostly the 150-180

Brazil is already at 127000 deaths (Sept 8).  and August alone had approximately 40000 deaths. Thus, there will easily be over 150000 deaths by Oct 1.  https://ourworldindata.org/coronavirus/country/brazil?country=~BRA
23 days to go, over 1k average per day needed to get to 150k.  Rates slightly decreasing, so going more to bin 3

126203 as of 6 September. 25 days to go, so an average below 952 would be enough to stay in bin 3. 
7-day moving average far lower than that (at 827), trend slowly down. Number of new infections stable. Looks good.

As of yesterday 126k deaths total, yesterday total 888 deaths.  26 days to go until problem cutoff date. If average daily death is 850 the total will be 148,100. If average death rate daily is 925, the total will be 150,050. I can understand the venal behavior associated with trying to fix and bet on the Nobel Prize foru Literature as we saw happen couple years ago.  But the divisiveness this is causing by tearing  the social fabric of a nominal democracy in Brazil is pure mendacity.
The numbers are going the right way again.

Rerun the numbers 1) Weekly number of deaths: 6090 +/- 80
2) Weekly growth/decrease factor (from 7 to 21 days ago): x = 0.957 +/- 0.044
3) Weekly growth/decrease factor required to reach 150K deaths: x > 1.051 This indicates that the factor x (the ratio of death during one week compared to the previous one) is two sigmas away from the threshold required to reach 150K deaths. The probabilities are 98.3% less than 150K and 1.7% more than 150K. However I move a little bit on the higher buckets owing to the possibility of revised number of deaths, for instance.
The numbers are going in the wrong direction.

Currently 124,000 and over 800 deaths a day. Brazil has had a prolonged plateau that is only just starting to decrease. The majority of countries death curves are positively skewed and the rate drops slowly than it increased. I expect the death rate to be between 800 and 600 a day for the next month, which gives a range of 18000-24000 more deaths. https://ourworldindata.org/coronavirus/country/brazil?country=~BRA. based on our world in data.

As of 3rd September it is 122,596 deaths.
Last 7 days average was around 860.
For the remaining 27 days, this projects to 23,220 new deaths, bringing the total to about 146k. Two weeks ago the average deaths were around 960, which shows a downwards trend. So, if anything, the trend is that every week the average will drop. For 150k to be crossed, there need to be 27,400 deaths in 27 days, or upwards of 1,000/day on average. That is not very likely.
Assuming they don't revise it up. Given that they don't even report test positivity data I estimate that as a low probability event.
It seems that they will come in around 140K considering current death counts and trends.

121381 as of 1 September (WHO seems to have had a data problem yesterday, when they said it was >123K), 30 days to go. 7-day moving average of deaths below 900, daily new cases increasing a little again.

Average of deaths at or below 953 per day for bin 3 looks very realistic to me.

Coming back to this, it looks like the growth rate is dropping below 1%. Projecting from today with an 0.8% growth rate through to the end of the month puts it at 152k. Right on the edge. The growth rate and number of cases per day do seem to be dropping, though, so it seems more likely to fall on the lower side. With that said, folks are back at beaches and Bolsonaro is winning the narrative on COVID [1]. I'm putting this at 50/50 [1] https://www.americasquarterly.org/article/rios-beaches-are-proof-bolsonaro-is-winning-the-narrative-on-covid-19/
Narrowing forecast now that there is less uncertainty with one month remaining - seems like deaths are declining from 1000/day average and with 30 days left and~28k deaths before 150k total
Moving a significant chunk from Bin 4 to Bin 3. The numbers are trending down and haven’t been consistently over 1k/day in the last few weeks.

In the last few days a new trend for new Deaths from COVID-19 per day in brazil can be observed that follows the linear approximation  f(x) = 1.6361*x^2 - 6.9014*x + 1007.9 with a coefficient of determination R^2 = 0,9931. If this is a correct approximation for the next 31 days there will be another 7K another new deaths as of 1 October 2020. While the current number is 119,504 the total deaths as of 1 Ocotober 2020 will be approximately 127K. Assuming a linear approximation the function is  f(x) = -19,99*x + 1027 with a coefficient of determination R^2=0,9731 If this is the correct approximation for the next 31 days there will be another 17K new deaths until 1 October 2020. Therefore the number of deaths will be 137K.  The range to land on 1 October according to this models therefore is [127K,137K]. Increasing the probability for [120K,150K). 
As a new outbreak can happen any day I set the likelihood for [150K,180K) to 20%. raw data used to create this models was found here: http://91-divoc.com/pages/covid-visualization/?chart=countries&highlight=Brazil&show=25&y=both&scale=linear&data=deaths-daily-7&data-source=jhu&xaxis=right-4wk#countries
If it continued for a month at the current rate it would be bin 3. Have to keep checking as rates have a way of changing though Brazil has been consistently bad.

There are 33 days between now and October 1st. Brazil has about 119k deaths from COVID-19 and had an average of 940 deaths per day this past week. If we extrapolate, that suggests Brazil will have almost exactly 150k deaths on October 1st. The number of cases recorded per day has not really changed at all over the past month, so it seems very probable that the death rate will remain pretty similar over the next month. It seems to me to be a 50/50 for whether the number of deaths exceeds 150,000.
Shifting 1% per day as long as the numbers go into the right direction.
Go with an optomistic view and hope for the better.

With the 7 day moving average under the required average to stay in bin 3 (thanks @pstamp ), and the overall trend being downwards, the chances of bin 3 are increasing day by day. My own projection is ~ 145k - 148k by Oct 1st.
First time: 7-day moving average under the required average to stay in bin 3. Three months of a nightmare-plateau seem to come to an end very slowly now. I wish Brazil all the best!

As of 3:32pm CEST, 26 August 2020, Brazil had 115,309 reported deaths on the WHO website. From August 13th to August 26th, average daily was 962. With 35.15 days remaining, this results in a projection of, drum roll, 149.123.  It will be a tight squeeze, folks! Can we do more with the data? I assume that there is weekly seasonality (i.e. fewer deaths reported on weekends), so I took at 7-day moving average for the last 100 days. There is a downtrend in the data and 850-1025 daily deaths average look feasible as a range. This gives a narrow target corridor of 145k to 151k, with a 70-80% chance for the lower bin. I allocate 2/3 and 1/3 to allow for the risk of upside adjustment, as happened for example in India, as we all know that a lot more people have already died >>probably<< because of Covid in Brazil.
7 day moving average of deaths is falling and has been below 1000 for last 11 days. Chances of ending on the lower side 150k are increasing
Brazil is finally getting some relief from the horrendous numbers.
The death rate is about 1200 per day on average so the final death toll should be somewhere around 145,000.

Today's stats from Brazil's press consortium-  https://g1.globo.com/bemestar/coronavirus/noticia/2020/08/25/casos-e-mortes-por-coronavirus-no-brasil-em-25-de-agosto-segundo-consorcio-de-veiculos-de-imprensa.ghtml

114250 as of 24 August, 38 days to go. Daily average of <940 for bin 3, >940 for bin 4 (and 1730 for bin 5, so let´s forget about that). The 7 day moving average is still close to 1000, so why am I so optimistic to join the "70:30 gang"?
1) 7 day moving average went down about 100 in the past month; if that trend continues (and I think so, as the number of daily new cases went down even sharper in that time), all will be fine for bin 3
2) the next 2 days on WHO will be lower (their data is 2 days behind worldometers), and the last days will be the lower numbers for the weekend before 1 October, giving a little advantage there, too.
This is going down to the wire.
Nothing is for sure in the next 38 days.

This is a really tough one if we want to pin down on which side of 150K deaths we will end. As in many other places, the weekly number of deaths has been following a clearly discernible exponential (in this case decreasing) pattern: DeathBR (day_n) - DeathBR (day_n-7) = x  (DeathBR (day_n-7) - DeathBR (day_n-14) )  for the last 21 days, the mean and variance of x has been: x = 0.980 +/- 0.033 which, curiously, is not enough to distinguish in a statistical significant way whether the deaths are simply growing linearly or whether they are showing a soft exponential decrease. Now, to end below the 150K bucket, we need x < 0.987, which is like 0.25 sigmas below the central value. From this, it is about a 58% probability to end up below 150K, but I remove a bit of probability just in case there is a big revision of the data, maybe going up (more probably) or down (that could also happen). Yet this revision does not need to move things from one bucket to another. Now, of course there is a fly in the ointment here: the error I have provided for x is for the change of one week to the next. The correct way to calculate the probability will be to notice that there are five weeks, and thus we are throwing the dice of "how many cases we will have next week" five times. This indicates that the real variance over five weeks is 1/sqrt(5) the one I gave, which will sharpen the probabilities of being below 150K to 68% (instead of 58%). However I have decided to err on the "overestimate my own errors" side. EDIT: the last comment is only correct if I want to calculate the expected weekly deaths in five weeks time. But we are summing, and thus error compound in a more complicated manner (the error of the first week will be sigma, for the second week sigma / sqrt(2), for the third, sigma / sqrt(3), etc., then the error of their sum would be sigma * sqrt(1 + 1/4 + 1/9 + 1/16 + 1/25) = 1.21 sigma, which actually it is extremely close to sigma and this is probably why this approach has been somehow useful in the past, despite being so crude.

As of today, Aug 22nd, Brazil has 113,358 deaths.
The daily average of the last 7 days is 976 deaths per day (weekends tend to report less deaths, so the averaging must be made on a weekly basis - or multiples of a week).
With 9 days remaining in August and 30 days in September, the projected deaths total by end of September is 151.422.
Still a close call, but it seems that the 150k will likely be crossed, the 1.422 extra projected is equivalent of almost two days’ worth of casualties, therefore a significant ‘buffer’. I assign two-thirds probability that it will be crossed, and expect to increase that if the rate persists.
49 days to report.  Average of 750 per day needed to hit 150k.  It’s still close but as the weekly average is still hovering at about 900 am moving forecast from bin 3 to 4.
112,000 now and numbers decreasing. Could be close.

The WHO stats are not respected by the current government in Brazil, which holds the WHO in low regard following the lead of the White House. WHO link https://covid19.who.int/table You can deep dive and find a dearth of articles alleging that the government of Brazil is underreporting deaths,  or experiencing administrative "lag time" due to the quaintness of local and state reporting behaviors.  Some of which, like The Intercept, are full of invective.   Brazil still operates with an interim health minister who is-- still-- not a MD,  an active duty army 3 star general background in supply and logistics (which makes some sense in the context of Brazilian military logic), who also supports use of controversial malaria drug Clorquina to fight Covid-19.  And on his watch, the health ministry has been staffed up with several senior  active duty and "reserve" status officers.  In what may foreshadow the appointment of a "new" interim minister by the president, the current interim minister, Gen. Eduardo Pazuello, according to Globo and Folha de Sao Paulo, is under some pressure from senior military men who comprise the president's praetorian guard, to declare formally that he is going on "reserve status" or if he will be continuing as activive duty.  The current interim minister has, according to several media reports,  downplayed the number of total deaths, underreported them, or just not making them part of the daily report his ministry issues usually via social media.  If you read Brazilian portuguese here is link to Globo story about this issue, which also cites Folha de Sao Paulo
https://g1.globo.com/politica/noticia/2020/08/18/pazuello-vai-deixar-comando-da-12a-regiao-militar-informa-ministerio-da-saude.ghtml

989 deaths average over last 7 days according to Worldofmeters data, and 42 days remaining until "approximately 5pm ET on Oct 1st" from current 112423 vs 109888 on WHO.. it could really be either side of the 50k if the level keeps as stable as it has been since mid June.

I wonder how on earth so many countries manage to cut almost in half their cases AND fatalities at the same time all at once.
I can only imagine that the new, likely digitized, reporting framework of the W.H.O. will have a rocky start with sputters and stutters. If so, I hope they will come over it soon, and hold steady for a few more days.
43 days until October 1st, recent rate is about 9,000 deaths every 10 ten days. Case growth looks to be slowing a bit and deaths lag cases so I think 120 to 150 is most likely.

First time we've seen a "lower low" in active cases, as "winter" (at least in the South) is coming to an end. Maybe it is time to be cautiously optimistic? It surely is not down to policy, but a reprieve I think is nonetheless likely.
https://www.worldometers.info/coronavirus/country/brazil/

107852 today, 44 days to go. To stay below 150K we need a daily average below 958, which is a little less than the current 7 -day moving average of 971 according to worldometers. 
Another reason, why I will not start new Covid 19 questions (!!!!): with the new source I need to calculate time zones, which was not necessary, when WHO just published a report once a day. This might be so close, that one single day could make the difference.
Sufficiently reducing case rate to most likely make the final number below 150k - not by much, but an increasing trend will now be needed for result to be higher than 150k.

Considering current total deaths around 106K and about 1000 reported daily for the past week (although this is slightly trending downward).  With 45 days left, deaths would just exceed 150K at the current rate of daily deaths.  It is just as likely (Or a bit more likely) they could be just under 150K if current downward trend continues - even at it’s current rate of decrease, which is a slight 2%.

The daily increase is stable with approximately 1007.4 cases per day [1]. It is 64 days until 1 October 2020.
As of today there are 88,539 total deaths attributed to COVID-19 [2].  
88,539 + 64 * 1k = 153k total deaths attributed to COVID-19 as of 1 October 2020. [1] http://91-divoc.com/pages/covid-visualization/?chart=countries&highlight=Brazil&show=25&y=both&scale=linear&data=deaths-daily-7&data-source=jhu&xaxis=left#countries
[2] http://91-divoc.com/pages/covid-visualization/?chart=countries&highlight=Brazil&show=25&y=both&scale=linear&data=deaths&data-source=jhu&xaxis=left#countries ----
Update 16 Aug 2020:
104k + (45 * 1k) = 149k The dynamic of new infections and new deats is slowing down so that less than 150k total deaths attributed to COVID-19 reported by the World Health Organization (WHO) is more and more probable.

Average deaths 1,000 per day is consistent since end May. I don't see it easing (or accelarating) since it has been stable at that level since end May.
With 16 days remaining in August and 30 in September, total 46 days, that is about 46.000 new deaths till end September. On top of current 105,000 deaths, that is total of 151,000, smack in between the two middle brackets. I am adjusting to 50%-50%.
There are about 45 days remaining in the period.

If Brazil holds at about 1% average, my production puts it at about 165k. If it drops down a bit in the next few weeks (I'm estimating another two weeks at 1%, and the remaining 4 at 0.8%), this puts it at about 156k. Projecting out at 1k per day (average in absolute terms over the last few weeks), which it has been holding at for the full duration, with a slight drop, that puts it at 150k. I am dropping slightly.
Right now are 101,752 with 703 new deaths; daily deaths vary a lot; so let's use an average of 500 -> that will give us another 22k deaths approx. depends what happens in the next weeks..

50 days to go.  101k today running at average of about 1k per day brings very close to 150k still.  Trend is slightly reducing meaning probability of less than 150k and bin 3 looks most likely.  Upping forecast for bin 3.
On August 10 about 100,000. 900+ new deaths. that day.  51 days to go to October 1.

Currently as of August 10th Brazil has 100,477 deaths (rounding at 100k). Last 7 days had an average of 987 deaths per day. The week before looks about the same. So, if we take the bookends approach:
- To reach to 120k deaths it needs to be average of only 370 deaths per day until end of Sept. Too low, which means the 120k threshhold is bound to be crossed (assuming reporting continues and is not politically manipulated, I will choose to ignore any political manipulation of numbers).
- With a low average of 600 deaths per day for the next 54 days, we get to ~133k deaths by end of Sept.
- With a high average of 1000 deaths per day for the next 54 days, we get to ~155k deaths by end of Sept.
- I expect today's average of 987 to drop in September, assuming the country gets over the peak. But, between 600 and 1,000 average deaths, it will be closer to the high, maybe 800-900.
- The 150k threshold is crossed when average is ~925 deaths per day.
- So, between the 120-150k and the 150-180k bracket, I am leaning somewhat more towards the lower.
- If it is a normal distribution, with a mean of 800 deaths per day, and a P90 of 1000 deaths/day, then the 925 deaths per day sits at  cumulative probability of 56%. I round up to 60% because I believe in it slowing down, more than I believe in maintaining a plateau of 800 or increasing, so I believe my normal distribution should be skewed to the lower end of it. Note to self: I should follow this question on a weekly basis.

Daily Covid-19 deaths in Brazil are quite volatile but have averaged around 850 since May. As this is the 'winter flu season' for the parts of the country that do exhibit seasonal patterns, some relief is possible from September onwards. Otherwise, there is not much in terms of policy or behavior that suggests a sea-change prior to conclusion of this question. With 50 days remaining, 135k-155k is the most likely range for the death toll by 1 Oct, with corrections and surprises far more likely to the upside (as we are just seeing the 20% or so tip of the iceberg for Covid-19 cases globally anyway).

Brazil fatality rate continues to be similar to the US rate which could result in a 150K number by 1 Oct.
https://ig.ft.com/coronavirus-chart/?areas=bra&areas=usa&areasRegional=usny&areasRegional=usnj&areasRegional=ustx&cumulative=0&logScale=1&perMillion=0&values=deaths

The projections show a potential of between 160,000 and 200,000 deaths, caused by Covid-19 in Brazil by 1st October 2020.
The high rate appears to be had been achieved by Government inaction and belief in the severity of the pandemic (especially for the President – who now has it).
An essential part of a program to inhibit the infection rate upon the population is to instigate an efficient track and trace system that involves an appropriate volume of testing laboratories.
Germany achieved this by having available such private labs that could achieve results in a minimum time.
Brazil, like the UK has a centralised public system of testing that may suffer from miscommunicating  between competing management organisations that result in disfunction. (A possible question to ask Good Judgment as to percentage successes between the two systems and assist in future pandemics).
It should be noted that Brazil is still experiencing the first wave of infection, with future waves to arrive. https://medicalxpress.com/news/2020-08-brazil-virus-deaths-october-expert.html  https://covid19-projections.com/brazil  https://covid19.healthdata.org/brazil  http://www.healthdata.org/news-release/new-ihme-covid-19-model-forecasts-more-166000-deaths-brazil-october-1  https://www.worldometers.info/coronavirus/country/brazil/  https://www.reuters.com/article/us-health-coronavirus-brazil-testing/as-brazils-covid-19-testing-lags-available-labs-go-unused-idUSKCN21X36V

https://www.telegraph.co.uk/global-health/science-and-disease/brazil-became-south-americas-covid-19-hotspot/  https://www.reuters.com/article/us-health-coronavirus-brazil-brasilia/early-reopening-turns-brazils-capital-into-covid-19-hot-spot-idUSKBN24B1DM

With about 50 days to go the rate of increase is still linear with no indication of a reduction. Still expect that some reduction may be seen by the end of this question, but might be close to the 150k mark.
https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-latin-america-53712087

I’ve kind of been arm waving this forecast since June, but I’m sensing a fairly consistent pattern. Every day, WHO reports another 1000 deaths, give or take. There are some day-to-day deviations, but for every day a few hundred less than a thousand are reported, there is another day of a few hundred more. With 98.5k total cases and 54 days left, I’m leaning toward the count on October 1 being just above 150k. I don’t see any real push from Bolsonaro to reign this in between now and then. I also don’t see anything that would greatly increase daily deaths to push the total over 180k.
https://www.cnbc.com/2020/07/22/brazil-politics-mixed-messages-hurt-response.html
94104 today.slight drop off in rates, so need a about 950 per day to reach 150k.  Swinging forecast to bin 3 a bit.

Minor adjustment towards 150-180k bracket. There is still no roll off of numbers which I had expected by now. Any down turn in the increase I still expect to put the final numbers into the 120-150k bracket, but I'm less certain of it now.

Per the FT chart, new cases had a marked up turn in the last week, this will likely increase the death rate during August and September.  Hattip @Tolga for analysis causing me to look again.
https://ig.ft.com/coronavirus-chart/?areas=usa&areas=gbr&areas=bra&areasRegional=usny&areasRegional=usca&areasRegional=usfl&areasRegional=ustx&cumulative=0&logScale=1&perMillion=0&values=cases

I´m staying stubborn, going against the crowd a little longer at least. 
Stable number of daily deaths around 1000 for more than two months already is something, that didn´t happen in any other country so far. In countries doing enough tests it´s always one or several sigmoid functions (either overlapping at the same time (different areas) or after one another as "waves"), but being linear for so long on such a high level is unique. It should be going up or down, not staying flat so long. Possible reasons:
- limited testing capacity (no, they are doing 61500 per 1 million population)
- political will (in that case the reported numbers would go down, when the real ones do, so that it looks a little more credible to external observers who can see trends even if they don´t know correct numbers).

Based on new cases I estimate that sometime in the next few weeks daily deaths will increase to somewhere between 1200 - 1300 and stay there for at least a couple of weeks. Based on this I am lead to believe the total will probably end up somewhere in the 150,000 - 180,000 range.  However I am unable to find any test positivity data for Brazil, and this makes me very uncertain about this prediction. In the absence of this increase above 1200 I will be going 100% into the 120,000 - 150,000 bucket.

Based on looking at the data from an absolute perspective (HT @SE_Meyer [1]), with about 1k deaths per day with a slow increase in peaks, that further backs up about 150k cases. Looking at some of the latest reports from Brazil [2], there doesn't seem to be much patience from Bolsonaro or many citizens for masks, social distancing or other measures, which looks like there won't be too much of a decrease any time soon. Bumping to more in the 150k bin, and putting a small bit at the top to account for any severe spikes. [1] https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1094667

Try to sum up the opinion of the crowd here: it might look like a boring "linear thing" shooting at somewhere slighytly above 150K with a little risk to even go up and a small chance to get much better soon. General expectation: "usually it gets better after a while, but this looks like staying linear (for whatever reasons) much longer than everywhere else". My assumption so far was similar: take the most likely scenarios and place your bets around their average accordingly. Boring, but effective most of the time. I´d like to add something to the equation, which leads me away from the crowd and especially from the more experienced people here.
Simple idea: if the setting is relatively under control (most important: concerning numbers of tests), it makes sense to look at other numbers: ratio of active cases vs. recovered; critical cases; cases/1 M population; most important for this question: deaths/1 M population. Believe it or not: Brazil does not look so bad with those numbers. In other words: to go from 88K to 150K in 2 months (after having analyzed many other countries) they would need to be much worse. And they would need to have the worst number of deaths/1 M population of all. In other words: there is a limit of how bad it can get, and >150K is outside of what I believe about it.Comments welcome.

As of today (20 July), 72 days remain till July 20. WHO reports 79,488 deaths so far in Brazil. The deaths per day (dpd) corresponding to the various cut-offs of total covid fatalities for 1 October are as follows: 90,000 deaths - 146 dpd
120,000 deaths - 562.7 dpd
150,000 deaths -  979.3 dpd
180,000 deaths -  1396 dpd As one can check, since June 5th, the 7-day rolling average (hence the average dpd) for Brazil has been almost constant around 1000 approx. Assuming this trend will continue (and making no speculation as to whether the dpd will increase or decrease, if it moves at all, and to what extent), it is reasonable to conclude that the actual outcome will be a dpd of around 1k + or - 200 (at worst). This rules out <90k, 90k-120k and >180k. Among the rest, the range of 800-1200 dpd (which is where  the predicted dpd from today till oct 1 will most likely lie) overlaps a bit more with the range 150k-180k (dpd between 979.3 and 1396) than 120k-150k (dpd between 562.7 and 979.3). In addition I think the dpd will increase if  it changes significantly from 1k at all (and we might get people added to the list of fatalities who died earlier but are subsequently identified as covid fatalities like in India and some other countries). Hence my assigned probabilites.

Models people have suggested will miss a few things. These are: 1. Every country has an ICU bed and ventilator limit, after which mortality will spike 100-500%. Brazil is already teetering on the edge in places like Manaus and Brasilia. If you go from 40k new cases per day to 80k, mortality for the guys that get the ventilators will be 0.5%, for the ones that don't it'll be 1-5%. 2. Retrospective changes in cause of death are included in this question. Most countries, after the frenzy of the first wave, have gone back and revised their death totals, from what I've seen all in one direction (up).

Simple exponential regressions for day-over-day percent change in cases and deaths (even for extended period questions) have worked well for me so far. Applying that method to this question gets me roughly 94k deaths by Oct 1st.  That being said, there are a couple factors that make me unsure:
1. “seasonal pattern” to the daily residuals are not very stable right now. That could swing my forecast over time (most likely up)
2. Brazil’s mitigation efforts were minimal early on but ICU hospitalizations and deaths are plateauing (we’ll see how this evolves. A stronger response could pose a downside risk to my forecast (upside from a humanitarian perspective). 
3. Brazil has came under scrutiny last month for under-reporting and withholding COVID-19 data (https://www.wsj.com/articles/brazil-draws-scrutiny-for-changes-to-coronavirus-data-reporting-11591652332). Such a lack of transparency increases the risk of an adjustment. In my mind, this risk is tilted towards the upside (due to WHO action), but is the reason behind my 10% in the <90k bin Will continue to monitor and adjust accordingly

On April 1st - Brazil had around 250 deaths. Over the next 3 months (April, May & June) - an additional 60k people died.  Now assume that the daily death chart (https://www.worldometers.info/coronavirus/country/brazil/) inverts on 1st July and dies out over the next 3 months (July, August & September).  This is an OPTIMISTIC scenario. Still on 1st October there will be 120k + people dead in Brazil from covid-19. Hence assign a NIL probability to the 1st 2 buckets. A REALISTIC scenario would assume the average deaths/day remains at the current level (1000 deaths) for the 3 months (July, August, September). This would add 90k deaths to the initial 60k deaths for a total of 150k deaths.  A PESSIMISTIC scenario would assume 1000 deaths/day for 45 days and 1500 deaths/day for the next 45 days.  This would give a total of 112.5k and a total of 172.5k deaths. This is well possible because of the large Brazilian population and a relative lower spread (currently) in some of the larger provinces.  So my forecast:
Fewer than 90k                                                -     0%
90k - 120k                                                         -     5%
120k - 150k                                                       -   25%
150k - 180k                                                       -   55%
More than 180k                                               -   15% NOTE - Death numbers are susceptible to revision and its usually upwards (previous deaths now attributed to covid-19). So if a calculation yields 150k (I would like to thing of it as a range from 140k - 170k).

Too many factors to list but poor handling shows they are likely to follow similar-sh trajectory to the US, with a similar-ish population size (and a similar-ish government with similar priorities and political outlooks).  On one hand the population is younger than in developed countries (an advantage) and on the other a very high proportion of poor and extremely poor people make up the general population, affecting health and access to healthcare. There's the risk of Bolsorano attempting (again) to suppress coronavirus data, making it difficult for the WHO to publish accurate results. Another risk is the WHO ceasing to publish Brazil data in the event of Brazil withdrawing from the WHO (which Bolsorano has threatened previously). He seems to have threatened this on the back of the US announcement to withdraw themselves, but considering Trump's dwindling poll numbers and the court and public backlash at home that forced Bolsorano to restart Covid data publication, he may take a step back to wait and see how Trump's handling of the virus plays out in the US election in early November. This is why I take the view that the likely numbers will be between 90k-120k, with a higher death count less likely (due to potential treatments being developed between now and then, possible data suppression closer to the end of September and/or WHO withdrawal).  In addition, there are more situations leading to publication of <90k deaths than there are leading to publication of more than 150k deaths given all of the above. should no interference take place and no major medical developments made, will fall into the 90k-120k bracket. Tl;dr with politics and medical developments absent I think the death count would be in the 90k-120k range, but risk of data suppression/WHO withdrawal and possibility of new treatments skewer the likely outcome such that, whether accurate or not, an outcome of <90k deaths being published is more probable than >120k
The curve is flattening. 2 week average (~1000/day) is flat. Daily deaths seem to be going down. Readjusting the forecast to lower numbers

I’m starting my forecast with some balance with the lower end of the spectrum. It seems like Brazil has a lot of things going against it: president resistant to enforcing social distancing, anti government protest, etc. My prior is that in most countries, they find a way to get the first wave of this virus under control with things weighing me higher being the political factors when compared to other countries.  Counterpoints include some regions enforcing their own social distancing.  https://covid19-projections.com/brazil

the rate of change has been declining and currently sits at ~8%.  I calculated the average rate from now until October at 5%, compounded every 4 days, resulting in 175000 total mortalities.  I’m skewing over the >180000 mark

Brazil has recorded an average of ~1000 coronavirus deaths for the past several weeks, and with 93 days until Oct 1st this would be an additional ~93k deaths on top of the ~59k recorded so far. Many deaths are not being recorded, so it’s impossible to know the true toll or rate of spread. It is likely that Brazil will not control its spread, however, so unless numbers are fudged <150k deaths by then seems unlikely. There remains a possibility for a massive growth in death toll with exponential spread.

Rate of death seems to decline more quickly than case numbers, across many countries. Perhaps for differing reasons; improved experience of medical staff, new knowledge/treatments shared as crisis continues, or possibly that as the younger population becomes more infected their increased survival rate improves the stats. Either way I predict a marginal decline in the rate of death over three months, from 30K/month to approx 22-27K. Worst case would tip into 4th bin.

I will try to refine the previous forecast: for the past few weeks we have been having a linear increase in deaths in Brazil. Every week there are about 7000 new deaths. It is difficult to say whether this is due to misreporting or because the pandemic is not in its explosive phase anymore. During May one could observe a stay increase in the numbers of deaths. Now, if this trend continues, we should end up with 150K deaths by the deadline. Just between the two buckets. If this trend is reversed and somehow Brazil bends the curve, we will below this number. Besides, the new Dexamethasone treatment could reduce the number of deaths, somewhere between 20-30% for people with respiratory complications, which could decrease the weekly deaths into the 4000-5500 range in a best case scenario. This indicates that we might need to err on the low side, instead of the high side as usual. The first thing is to determine the minimum number of deaths that we can expect: if the new cases curve somehow bended today, we will still have at least two more weeks of a linear regime before seeing a bending of deaths. This puts us into the 70K deaths minimum. Now, if somehow the deaths begin to reduce by a factor of 0.8-0.9 per week (somehow in the range of the reduction in Italy (0.75) or the US (0.88) for weekly deaths), this will add to about 98-133K deaths. This would be the floor. Besides this, from time to time there are revisions on the numbers of deaths. This could happen in Brazil, and most probably would be a revision upwards. If this is the case, the higher buckets will become more probable. Yet this is too optimistic: the inflection point is probably going to come later. But for the moment let us assume that this happens and that we take the value in the middle: 116K deaths. This excludes the first bucket and makes the second bucket improbable. With this I approximate the buckets as {0, 5, 50, 35, 10} for the moment.
Rate still going up. Not much leadership on strategies to reduce spread. Death rate is about 4% of reported cases so I think we'll hit 90K by the end of July. If so, I'll readjust things upward.

The current growth rate of deaths per the WHO is around 1.5-2.5% increase per day [1]. If that were to hold, the projection (using a 2% growth rate) would be around 365k, deaths by October. 90k would be reached by July 21st, and 180k by Aug 25th. This seems to be the "do nothing" result, which Bolsonaro isn't quite doing, but he also sure isn't projecting a clear message [2]. This may leave the local authorities to do much of the work of keeping things in check, much like has happened in the US -- which has resulted in a patchwork of rules and outbreaks. The US growth rate of deaths for the past few weeks has been closer to 0.5 -1% [3]. The highest reached when NY was at its worst, was around 7-10% increase. With that in mind, I'd predict 2% for the next couple weeks, probably a higher spike to 10% for a week, then a drop to 1% for a month, then 0.5% for the duration. That puts the total at 200k.  Putting most of it in the last bin, and the remainder split between the two below due to this being a SWAG of a model. [1] https://covid19.who.int/region/amro/country/br

This question is trying to predict the tail from the trend till now. I will do a more detailed analysis later but just noted that 2-2.5 months after reaching the peak in number of daily cases, the number of deaths was 4 times the cumulative death on the date of new cases peak.
If the average number of daily new cases remains above 30k and the death rate remains 0.045, they will be above 180k deaths just before 10/01.

Unlikely to slow rate anytime soon. Some leighway given at prospect that either declarations of deaths will be compromised or viable treatments are available by September. For that reason alone, guarded from 180K+ deaths.
